[File: aptos-core/api/openapi-spec-generator/src/main.rs] [Function: OutputArgs::write()] [Path Traversal] Can an attacker supply a malicious path via --output-path argument containing '../' sequences to write the OpenAPI spec to arbitrary locations outside intended directories, potentially overwriting critical system files? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/openapi-spec-generator/src/main.rs] [Function: OutputArgs::write()] [Symlink Attack] If the output_path points to a symbolic link, can an attacker create a symlink to a sensitive file before execution, causing the tool to overwrite that file with OpenAPI spec content? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/openapi-spec-generator/src/main.rs] [Function: OutputArgs::write()] [Directory Traversal] Does the write() function validate that the parent directory of output_path exists and is writable, or can it fail silently or create directories in unintended locations? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/openapi-spec-generator/src/main.rs] [Function: OutputArgs::write()] [File Permission Issues] When writing to output_path, are proper file permissions set, or could the generated spec file be world-writable, allowing unauthorized modification of the OpenAPI specification? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/openapi-spec-generator/src/main.rs] [Function: OutputArgs::write()] [TOCTOU Race Condition] Between checking if output_path exists and writing to it, could a race condition allow an attacker to replace the target with a symlink to a sensitive file (Time-of-Check-Time-of-Use vulnerability)? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/api/openapi-spec-generator/src/main.rs] [Function: main()] [Command Injection] If the tool is invoked programmatically with user-controlled arguments, can shell metacharacters in the output path cause command injection when the path is later used in shell scripts? (Low)

(Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/openapi-spec-generator/src/main.rs] [Struct: OutputFormat] [Enum Exhaustion] If new format variants are added to OutputFormat enum but not handled in the match statement in main(), can this cause a panic or incorrect spec generation? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/openapi-spec-generator/src/main.rs] [Function: main()] [Information Leak] Does the generated OpenAPI spec inadvertently expose internal API implementation details, debug endpoints, or sensitive configuration that should not be public? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/openapi-spec-generator/src/main.rs] [Function: OutputArgs::write()] [Disk Space Exhaustion] If output_path points to a filesystem with limited space, does write() handle disk-full errors gracefully, or can it corrupt the output file or crash? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/openapi-spec-generator/src/main.rs] [Function: main()] [Memory Exhaustion] When get_spec() generates the OpenAPI specification, is there a limit on the spec size, or can a maliciously constructed API service cause unbounded memory allocation and OOM crashes? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/api/openapi-spec-generator/src/main.rs] [Module: fake_context] [Mock Component Security] Are MockSharedMempool and MockDbReaderWriter properly isolated from real blockchain components, or could their use in spec generation accidentally expose real node data if contexts are mixed?
